elements.content: By employing a tricarboxylate ligand 1-(4-carboxybenzyl)-1H-pyrazole-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3L), four lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) formulated as {[LnL­(H2O)2]­·H2O} n (Ln = Eu, 1; Gd, 2; Tb, 3; Dy, 4) have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray analyses reveal that compounds 1–4 are isomorphous and exhibit a three-dimensional network structure featuring a one-dimensional rectangular channel with a size of ca. 7.8 Å × 12.1 Å along the b axis. The framework shows strong stabilities toward high temperature, humid air, water, as well as acid/base environments. Efficient ligand-sensitized characteristic luminescence can be observed in the visible region for Eu- and Tb-based compounds. Detailed property investigation shows that TbL is a promising multifunctional material, which can quantitatively detect Fe­(III) ions in the solution mixtures of Fe­(II)/Fe­(III), selectively adsorb CO2 over CH4, and be applied as catalysts in cyclization reaction with epoxides and CO2.
elements.clean_text: By employing a tricarboxylate ligand 1-(4-carboxybenzyl)-1H-pyrazole-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3L), four lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) formulated as {[LnL(H2O)2]⋅H2O} n  (Ln = Eu, 1; Gd, 2; Tb, 3; Dy, 4) have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. Single-crystal X-ray analyses reveal that compounds 1-4 are isomorphous and exhibit a three-dimensional network structure featuring a one-dimensional rectangular channel with a size of ca. 7.8 Å × 12.1 Å along the b axis. The framework shows strong stabilities toward high temperature, humid air, water, as well as acid/base environments. Efficient ligand-sensitized characteristic luminescence can be observed in the visible region for Eu- and Tb-based compounds. Detailed property investigation shows that TbL is a promising multifunctional material, which can quantitatively detect Fe(III) ions in the solution mixtures of Fe(II)/Fe(III), selectively adsorb CO2 over CH4, and be applied as catalysts in cyclization reaction with epoxides and CO2.

elements.content: We have designed and constructed a lanthanide metal−organic framework by utilizing a tricarboxylate linker with versatile coordination modes and Lewis basic sites. The framework shows a combination of high thermal, air, and chemical stabilities and can be used as a multifunctional material for Fe­(III) detection, CO2 capture, and utilization.
elements.clean_text: We have designed and constructed a lanthanide metal-organic framework by utilizing a tricarboxylate linker with versatile coordination modes and Lewis basic sites. The framework shows a combination of high thermal, air, and chemical stabilities and can be used as a multifunctional material for Fe(III) detection, CO2 capture, and utilization.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), a flourishing subclass of porous crystalline materials, have been developed quickly, ascribed to their prosperous applications in gas storage/separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and sensing in the past two decades. Among all these applications, MOFs incorporating functional sites and proper channels for host–guest recognition have attracted extensive attention, especially in sensing cations, anions, small organic molecules and biomarkers, as well as pH and temperature. As we know, the Fe­(III) ion is one of the indispensable elements for the human body and other biological systems. Both a shortage and surplus of Fe­(III) ions may result in somatic function disorders, such as iron deficiency anemia (IDA), skin diseases, agrypnia, and decreased immunity. Therefore, selective and quantitative detection of Fe­(III) ions is of great importance. Compared with other detection methods, fluorescence-based detection has proved to be a preeminent avenue for rapid detection of Fe­(III) ions attributed to its excellent sensitivity, unique selectivity, convenient operation, low cost, and visual detection. As a subgroup of MOFs, Ln-MOFs are considered as fascinating and promising sensing materials which combine the unique spectroscopic features of lanthanide ions and porous advantage of MOFs. In terms of fluorescence sensing, Eu-MOFs and Tb-MOFs are drawing increasing attention as effective materials for fluorescent probes due to their excellent luminescence properties, such as extremely sharp pure red or green emission, large Stokes shifts, and high quantum yields.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a flourishing subclass of porous crystalline materials, have been developed quickly, ascribed to their prosperous applications in gas storage/separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and sensing in the past two decades. Among all these applications, MOFs incorporating functional sites and proper channels for host-guest recognition have attracted extensive attention, especially in sensing cations, anions, small organic molecules and biomarkers, as well as pH and temperature. As we know, the Fe(III) ion is one of the indispensable elements for the human body and other biological systems. Both a shortage and surplus of Fe(III) ions may result in somatic function disorders, such as iron deficiency anemia (IDA), skin diseases, agrypnia, and decreased immunity. Therefore, selective and quantitative detection of Fe(III) ions is of great importance. Compared with other detection methods, fluorescence-based detection has proved to be a preeminent avenue for rapid detection of Fe(III) ions attributed to its excellent sensitivity, unique selectivity, convenient operation, low cost, and visual detection. As a subgroup of MOFs, Ln-MOFs are considered as fascinating and promising sensing materials which combine the unique spectroscopic features of lanthanide ions and porous advantage of MOFs. In terms of fluorescence sensing, Eu-MOFs and Tb-MOFs are drawing increasing attention as effective materials for fluorescent probes due to their excellent luminescence properties, such as extremely sharp pure red or green emission, large Stokes shifts, and high quantum yields.

elements.content: On the other hand, in recent years, CO2 has caught people’s attention not only because it is the predominant greenhouse gas causing global warming but also because it can be widely used in organic syntheses as a nontoxic, inexpensive, and renewable C1 resource. Numerous efforts have been devoted to CO2 storage, separation, fixation, and utilization. One of the most efficient ways is the additive reactions between epoxides and CO2 to form cyclic carbonates, critical reagents widely used in fine chemical industrial and pharmaceutical syntheses, while stable Ln-MOFs are considered as the promising materials in CO2 storage, separation, and catalysis due to their regular channels and Lewis acid/basic sites.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, in recent years, CO2 has caught people's attention not only because it is the predominant greenhouse gas causing global warming but also because it can be widely used in organic syntheses as a nontoxic, inexpensive, and renewable C1 resource. Numerous efforts have been devoted to CO2 storage, separation, fixation, and utilization. One of the most efficient ways is the additive reactions between epoxides and CO2 to form cyclic carbonates, critical reagents widely used in fine chemical industrial and pharmaceutical syntheses, while stable Ln-MOFs are considered as the promising materials in CO2 storage, separation, and catalysis due to their regular channels and Lewis acid/basic sites.

elements.content: On the basis of the above discussion, we employed the 1-(4-carboxybenzyl)-1H-pyrazole-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3L) ligand to construct Ln-MOFs, because this tricarboxylate linker with versatile coordination modes and Lewis base sites could promote the formation of a high-dimensional and multifunctional framework material. Finally, we have successfully obtained four novel three-dimensional (3D) Ln-MOFs {[LnL­(H2O)2]­·H2O} n (Ln = Eu, 1, Gd, 2, Tb, 3, Dy, 4), with high air, water, pH, and thermal stabilities which can be used as the Fe­(III) sensor, CO2 separation material, and catalyst in the reaction of CO2 cyclization with epoxides.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the above discussion, we employed the 1-(4-carboxybenzyl)-1H-pyrazole-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3L) ligand to construct Ln-MOFs, because this tricarboxylate linker with versatile coordination modes and Lewis base sites could promote the formation of a high-dimensional and multifunctional framework material. Finally, we have successfully obtained four novel three-dimensional (3D) Ln-MOFs {[LnL(H2O)2]⋅H2O} n  (Ln = Eu, 1, Gd, 2, Tb, 3, Dy, 4), with high air, water, pH, and thermal stabilities which can be used as the Fe(III) sensor, CO2 separation material, and catalyst in the reaction of CO2 cyclization with epoxides.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were of AR grade commercially available and used as received without further purification. The German Elementary Vario EL III instrument was used for elemental analyses. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were measured using the Netzsch model STA 449C instrument from ambient temperature to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under flowing nitrogen atmosphere. The IR spectra in the 400–4000 cm–1 region were collected with KBr slices on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. The temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on the Ultima-IV X-ray diffractometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on the Rigaku MiniFlex 600 diffractometer. Gas adsorption measurements were carried out on ASAP 2020 M gas adsorption analyzer. UV–vis study was recorded on a Lambda 365. Photoluminescence spectra of solid state samples were collected on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. Luminescence lifetimes were obtained on an Edinburgh Analytical Instruments FLS920, and the overall fluorescence quantum yields were measured by a calibrated integrating sphere at room temperature on Edinburgh Instruments FLS920 spectrofluorometer. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy was recorded on the Burker AVANCE 400 (400 MHz).
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

All reagents and solvents were of AR grade commercially available and used as received without further purification. The German Elementary Vario EL III instrument was used for elemental analyses. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were measured using the Netzsch model STA 449C instrument from ambient temperature to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under flowing nitrogen atmosphere. The IR spectra in the 400-4000 cm-1 region were collected with KBr slices on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. The temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on the Ultima-IV X-ray diffractometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on the Rigaku MiniFlex 600 diffractometer. Gas adsorption measurements were carried out on ASAP 2020 M gas adsorption analyzer. UV-vis study was recorded on a Lambda 365. Photoluminescence spectra of solid state samples were collected on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. Luminescence lifetimes were obtained on an Edinburgh Analytical Instruments FLS920, and the overall fluorescence quantum yields were measured by a calibrated integrating sphere at room temperature on Edinburgh Instruments FLS920 spectrofluorometer. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy was recorded on the Burker AVANCE 400 (400 MHz).

elements.content: A mixture of H3L (29 mg, 0.10 mmol) and Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O (45 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in a 10 mL binary solution (CH3CN/H2O = 1:1), which was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Then they were kept in a 130 °C oven for 72 h. After slowly being cooled to room temperature, the colorless crystals were collected by filtration, washed with CH3CN and ethanol, and dried in air. The total yields of EuL, GdL, TbL, and DyL are ca. 60%, 65%, 63%, and 61%, respectively, based on the metal ions. The elemental analyses are as follows.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [LnL(H2O)2]⋅H2O (Ln = Eu, Gd, Tb, and Dy) (Compounds EuL, GdL, TbL and DyL)

A mixture of H3L (29 mg, 0.10 mmol) and Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (45 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in a 10 mL binary solution (CH3CN/H2O = 1:1), which was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Then they were kept in a 130 °C oven for 72 h. After slowly being cooled to room temperature, the colorless crystals were collected by filtration, washed with CH3CN and ethanol, and dried in air. The total yields of EuL, GdL, TbL, and DyL are ca. 60%, 65%, 63%, and 61%, respectively, based on the metal ions. The elemental analyses are as follows.

elements.content:
[EuL­(H2O)2]·H2O (EuL) Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for EuC13H13N2O9, C, 29.68/29.49; H, 3.15/3.17; N, 5.27/5.22

[GdL­(H2O)2]·H2O (GdL) Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for GdC13H13N2O9, C, 29.61/29.21; H, 3.16/3.21; N, 5.26/5.24.

[TbL­(H2O)2]·H2O (TbL) Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for TbC13H13N2O9, C, 29.63/29.12; H, 3.13/3.20; N, 5.30/5.22.

[DyL­(H2O)2]·H2O (DyL) Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for DyC13H13N2O9, C, 29.08/28.93; H, 3.15/3.17; N, 5.20/5.19.

X-ray Crystallography

Crystallographic data of compounds 1–4 were collected on the SuperNova diffractometer equipped with a multilayer mirror Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). All structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 with SHELX-97. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 using the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program except some disordered water molecules. All the hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined using a riding model. The disordered solvents were removed by the SQUEEZE process. The final chemical formulas of the compounds 1–4 were calculated from solved results combined with thermogravimetric and elemental analyses. The CCDC numbers for 1–4 are 1814661–1814664. Detailed crystallographic data are attached in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
[EuL(H2O)2]⋅H2O (EuL) Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for EuC13H13N2O9, C, 29.68/29.49; H, 3.15/3.17; N, 5.27/5.22

[GdL(H2O)2]⋅H2O (GdL) Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for GdC13H13N2O9, C, 29.61/29.21; H, 3.16/3.21; N, 5.26/5.24.

[TbL(H2O)2]⋅H2O (TbL) Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for TbC13H13N2O9, C, 29.63/29.12; H, 3.13/3.20; N, 5.30/5.22.

[DyL(H2O)2]⋅H2O (DyL) Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for DyC13H13N2O9, C, 29.08/28.93; H, 3.15/3.17; N, 5.20/5.19.

X-ray Crystallography

Crystallographic data of compounds 1-4 were collected on the SuperNova diffractometer equipped with a multilayer mirror Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). All structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 with SHELX-97. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 using the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program except some disordered water molecules. All the hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined using a riding model. The disordered solvents were removed by the SQUEEZE process. The final chemical formulas of the compounds 1-4 were calculated from solved results combined with thermogravimetric and elemental analyses. The CCDC numbers for 1-4 are 1814661-1814664. Detailed crystallographic data are attached in Table S1.

elements.content: The collected PXRD patterns (Figure S2) are almost the same as the corresponding simulated ones, indicating phase purities of the compounds. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses (SCXRD) confirm that these four compounds are heterogeneous isomorphous and possess a similar three-dimensional network. Therefore, we choose TbL as a model to illustrate the structure in detail. TbL crystallizes in P1̅ space group, whose unit cell contains one Tb­(III) ion, one fully deprotonated [L]3– ligand, and two coordinated water molecules (a). The Tb­(III) center is nine-coordinated, and its coordination geometry is completed by five μ2-bridging and two monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms from four [L]3– ligands as well as two oxygen atoms from two coordinated water molecules. A pair of μ2-bridging carboxylic groups connect two symmetry-related lanthanide ions and produce a dual-core structure, which is further linked with each other to form an infinite [Tb2(μ2-COO)2] n chain (b). Each [L]3– ligand connects five Tb­(III) atoms through a μ5-bridging coordination mode as c shown. Every dual-core cluster is bridged with 11 other dual-core clusters by eight L3– (Figure S3), finally generating a neutral 3D framework. A one-dimensional (1D) rectangular channel with a size of ca. 7.8 Å × 12.1 Å can be seen from the direction of the b axis (d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description

The collected PXRD patterns (Figure S2) are almost the same as the corresponding simulated ones, indicating phase purities of the compounds. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses (SCXRD) confirm that these four compounds are heterogeneous isomorphous and possess a similar three-dimensional network. Therefore, we choose TbL as a model to illustrate the structure in detail. TbL crystallizes in P1̅ space group, whose unit cell contains one Tb(III) ion, one fully deprotonated [L]3- ligand, and two coordinated water molecules (a). The Tb(III) center is nine-coordinated, and its coordination geometry is completed by five μ2-bridging and two monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms from four [L]3- ligands as well as two oxygen atoms from two coordinated water molecules. A pair of μ2-bridging carboxylic groups connect two symmetry-related lanthanide ions and produce a dual-core structure, which is further linked with each other to form an infinite [Tb2(μ2-COO)2] n  chain (b). Each [L]3- ligand connects five Tb(III) atoms through a μ5-bridging coordination mode as c shown. Every dual-core cluster is bridged with 11 other dual-core clusters by eight L3- (Figure S3), finally generating a neutral 3D framework. A one-dimensional (1D) rectangular channel with a size of ca. 7.8 Å × 12.1 Å can be seen from the direction of the b axis (d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of the Tb­(III) ion in TbL. (Symmetry codes: A, 1 – x, −y, −z; B, x, y–1, z–1; C, −x, −y–1, −z; D, x, y–1, z. Tb, green; N, blue; O, red; C, gray). (b) 1D [Tb2(μ2-COO)2] n chain in TbL. (c) The coordination mode of ligand. (d) The 3D network of TbL viewed along the b axis.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of the Tb(III) ion in TbL. (Symmetry codes: A, 1 - x, -y, -z; B, x, y-1, z-1; C, -x, -y-1, -z; D, x, y-1, z. Tb, green; N, blue; O, red; C, gray). (b) 1D [Tb2(μ2-COO)2] n  chain in TbL. (c) The coordination mode of ligand. (d) The 3D network of TbL viewed along the b axis.

elements.content: In spite of the high performance in many fields, a crucial weakness which hinders the applications of MOFs is their low stability. Thus, a comprehensive stability investigation of the material was then carried out. The TGA data (Figure S4) demonstrate that the decomposition temperature of the framework is high up to 440 °C. The first weight loss appears in the range of ca. 30–100 °C, which corresponds to the removal of the water molecules in the pores. And the weight loss in the range of ca. 100–240 °C corresponds to the removal of the coordinated water. The X-ray thermodiffractogram of TbL was investigated to further explore the thermal stability of the framework (a). The result shows no obvious phase transition occurs when heated up to 180 °C, but some characteristic peaks become inconspicuous when we raise the temperature to 200 °C, suggesting that this framework could remain stable until heating up to 180 °C. For an air stability test, 40 mg of TbL was exposed to the open air for 7, 15, and 30 days with an average humidity of ca. 55%. The PXRD patterns were then recorded to test its air stability. The result shown in b suggests that TbL can keep its framework after exposure to the open air for more than 30 days. To test its water stability, 40 mg of TbL was soaked in 25 mL of water for 3, 7, 15, and 30 days. The corresponding PXRD results suggest that TbL possesses excellent stability to water (c). Chemical stability test was assessed by soaking the 40 mg of TbL in the aqueous solutions of pH = 1–14 for 48 h. Then, all the samples were filtered and washed 3 times and dried in air before PXRD experiments for pH stability tests. The result reveals that the framework can remain stable in a broad pH range (pH = 2–12) (d). Overall, this framework shows strong stabilities toward high temperature, humid air, water, as well as acid/basic environments.
elements.clean_text:
Framework Stability

In spite of the high performance in many fields, a crucial weakness which hinders the applications of MOFs is their low stability. Thus, a comprehensive stability investigation of the material was then carried out. The TGA data (Figure S4) demonstrate that the decomposition temperature of the framework is high up to 440 °C. The first weight loss appears in the range of ca. 30-100 °C, which corresponds to the removal of the water molecules in the pores. And the weight loss in the range of ca. 100-240 °C corresponds to the removal of the coordinated water. The X-ray thermodiffractogram of TbL was investigated to further explore the thermal stability of the framework (a). The result shows no obvious phase transition occurs when heated up to 180 °C, but some characteristic peaks become inconspicuous when we raise the temperature to 200 °C, suggesting that this framework could remain stable until heating up to 180 °C. For an air stability test, 40 mg of TbL was exposed to the open air for 7, 15, and 30 days with an average humidity of ca. 55%. The PXRD patterns were then recorded to test its air stability. The result shown in b suggests that TbL can keep its framework after exposure to the open air for more than 30 days. To test its water stability, 40 mg of TbL was soaked in 25 mL of water for 3, 7, 15, and 30 days. The corresponding PXRD results suggest that TbL possesses excellent stability to water (c). Chemical stability test was assessed by soaking the 40 mg of TbL in the aqueous solutions of pH = 1-14 for 48 h. Then, all the samples were filtered and washed 3 times and dried in air before PXRD experiments for pH stability tests. The result reveals that the framework can remain stable in a broad pH range (pH = 2-12) (d). Overall, this framework shows strong stabilities toward high temperature, humid air, water, as well as acid/basic environments.

elements.content: X-ray thermodiffractogram (a), air stability (b), water stability (c), and pH stability (d) analyses of TbL.
elements.clean_text: 2  X-ray thermodiffractogram (a), air stability (b), water stability (c), and pH stability (d) analyses of TbL.

elements.content: The luminescence emission intensity of LnMOFs depends on the efficiency of energy transfer from the organic ligand to lanthanide ions to a certain extent. When excited, the emission spectra of ligand, GdL, EuL, TbL, and DyL were measured and recorded in Figure S5, Figure S6, a, b, and Figure S7, respectively. The luminescence spectra of EuL, TbL, and DyL all show characteristic emission lines of the corresponding lanthanide ions: at 580, 592, 617, 653, and 699 nm for EuL, at 491, 543, 586, 653, and 696 nm for TbL, at 480, 573, 660, and 750 nm for DyL. The decay lifetimes and luminescent quantum yields of EuL, TbL, and DyL are shown in Table S2. The larger decay lifetimes and luminescent quantum yields of EuL and TbL indicate that Eu­(III) and Tb­(III) can be well sensitized by the ligand compared with the Dy­(III) ion.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The luminescence emission intensity of LnMOFs depends on the efficiency of energy transfer from the organic ligand to lanthanide ions to a certain extent. When excited, the emission spectra of ligand, GdL, EuL, TbL, and DyL were measured and recorded in Figure S5, Figure S6, a, b, and Figure S7, respectively. The luminescence spectra of EuL, TbL, and DyL all show characteristic emission lines of the corresponding lanthanide ions: at 580, 592, 617, 653, and 699 nm for EuL, at 491, 543, 586, 653, and 696 nm for TbL, at 480, 573, 660, and 750 nm for DyL. The decay lifetimes and luminescent quantum yields of EuL, TbL, and DyL are shown in Table S2. The larger decay lifetimes and luminescent quantum yields of EuL and TbL indicate that Eu(III) and Tb(III) can be well sensitized by the ligand compared with the Dy(III) ion.

elements.content: Excitation and emission spectra of EuL (a) and TbL (b) at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 3  Excitation and emission spectra of EuL (a) and TbL (b) at room temperature.

elements.content: Inspired by the excellent luminescent properties and water stability of TbL, we explored the application of TbL as luminescent probes for sensing metal ions. Five milligrams of TbL was dispersed in 4 mL of aqueous solution, and then the suspension was ultrasonicated for 30 min to form a well-distributed MOF suspension whose luminescence intensity was recorded as the blank. Then, 1 mL of different metal salts, Sr­(NO3)2, KNO3, Mg­(NO3)2, CsNO3, Fe­(NO3)2, NaNO3, Mn­(NO3)2, Ni­(NO3)2, Co­(NO3)2, Ba­(NO3)2, Cu­(NO3)2, and Fe­(NO3)3, with a molar concentration of 5 × 10–3 mol/L were added respectively to form well-distributed metal ion incorporated MOF suspensions for luminescence experiments. As shown in a, there is no significant change in the fluorescence intensity for most metal ions suspensions, but a pronounced quenching effect of Fe­(III) ions can be observed, indicating that TbL can selectively detect Fe­(III) ions through a luminescence quenching effect. The extent of quenching effect can be evaluated by the quenching effect coefficient (K sv), which is calculated according to the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M], where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensity of TbL before and after adding metal ions, and [M] is the molar concentration of metal ions. It shows the highest K sv value of 1.9 × 103 L/mol for Fe­(III) ions.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing for Fe(III) Cations

Inspired by the excellent luminescent properties and water stability of TbL, we explored the application of TbL as luminescent probes for sensing metal ions. Five milligrams of TbL was dispersed in 4 mL of aqueous solution, and then the suspension was ultrasonicated for 30 min to form a well-distributed MOF suspension whose luminescence intensity was recorded as the blank. Then, 1 mL of different metal salts, Sr(NO3)2, KNO3, Mg(NO3)2, CsNO3, Fe(NO3)2, NaNO3, Mn(NO3)2, Ni(NO3)2, Co(NO3)2, Ba(NO3)2, Cu(NO3)2, and Fe(NO3)3, with a molar concentration of 5 × 10-3 mol/L were added respectively to form well-distributed metal ion incorporated MOF suspensions for luminescence experiments. As shown in a, there is no significant change in the fluorescence intensity for most metal ions suspensions, but a pronounced quenching effect of Fe(III) ions can be observed, indicating that TbL can selectively detect Fe(III) ions through a luminescence quenching effect. The extent of quenching effect can be evaluated by the quenching effect coefficient (K sv), which is calculated according to the Stern-Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M], where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensity of TbL before and after adding metal ions, and [M] is the molar concentration of metal ions. It shows the highest K sv value of 1.9 × 103 L/mol for Fe(III) ions.

elements.content: (a) Luminescence intensity of the 5D4 → 7F5 transitions (543 nm) of TbL in 5 × 10–4 M different metal cations. (b) The luminescence image of corresponding Fe­(III) ions and Fe­(II) ions samples under the irradiation of UV light. (c) The fluorescence intensity of Fe­(III) ions and Fe­(II) ions aqueous solution with 1 mmol/L total concentration.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Luminescence intensity of the 5D4 → 7F5 transitions (543 nm) of TbL in 5 × 10-4 M different metal cations. (b) The luminescence image of corresponding Fe(III) ions and Fe(II) ions samples under the irradiation of UV light. (c) The fluorescence intensity of Fe(III) ions and Fe(II) ions aqueous solution with 1 mmol/L total concentration.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that, in spite of a prominent quenching effect to Fe­(III) ions, the emission of TbL remains almost unchanged to Fe­(II) ions. Thus, TbL may be act as the luminescent probe for Fe­(III) ions in the Fe­(III)/Fe­(II) solution mixtures and could monitor the oxidation extent of Fe in complicated systems, which plays a significant role not only in biology systems but also in industry. Here, we utilize TbL to measure the ratio of Fe­(III) ions as a prototype system to demonstrate the potential of TbL as a new tool for detecting the extent of hydrogen peroxide oxidization reaction of Fe­(II) to Fe­(III) ions in industry by luminescence measurements. The photoluminescent properties of TbL in the mixtures of Fe­(II) and Fe­(III) ions with different molar ratios were investigated, in which the total concentration of Fe­(II) and Fe­(III) ions is 1 mmol/L. As b shown, when the concentration of Fe­(III) ions increased, the luminescence emission of the suspension quenched gradually. It shows an obvious linear relation between fluorescence intensity and the concentration of Fe­(III) ions in the range of 0–0.8 mmol in the Fe­(III)/Fe­(II) mixed solution (c), indicating the concentration of Fe­(III) ions in this range can be well estimated.
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to note that, in spite of a prominent quenching effect to Fe(III) ions, the emission of TbL remains almost unchanged to Fe(II) ions. Thus, TbL may be act as the luminescent probe for Fe(III) ions in the Fe(III)/Fe(II) solution mixtures and could monitor the oxidation extent of Fe in complicated systems, which plays a significant role not only in biology systems but also in industry. Here, we utilize TbL to measure the ratio of Fe(III) ions as a prototype system to demonstrate the potential of TbL as a new tool for detecting the extent of hydrogen peroxide oxidization reaction of Fe(II) to Fe(III) ions in industry by luminescence measurements. The photoluminescent properties of TbL in the mixtures of Fe(II) and Fe(III) ions with different molar ratios were investigated, in which the total concentration of Fe(II) and Fe(III) ions is 1 mmol/L. As b shown, when the concentration of Fe(III) ions increased, the luminescence emission of the suspension quenched gradually. It shows an obvious linear relation between fluorescence intensity and the concentration of Fe(III) ions in the range of 0-0.8 mmol in the Fe(III)/Fe(II) mixed solution (c), indicating the concentration of Fe(III) ions in this range can be well estimated.

elements.content: In order to understand the mechanism of luminescence quenching of Fe­(III) ions suspension, the PXRD of the sample after fluorescence testing was measured (Figure S10). The unchanged pattern suggests that the quenching of photoluminescence has no relation with the crystallographic transformation, indicating that Fe­(III) ions would not induce framework collapse. According to UV–vis absorption spectra (Figure S11), the strong adsorption of the aqueous solution of Fe­(III) ions is in the range of 250–450 nm, while others do not overlap in this range, especially near the 283 nm. Therefore, there exists obvious competition of the absorption in excitation wavelength (283 nm) between TbL and the Fe­(III) ions water solution. Such competitive adsorption will significantly decrease the transfer efficiency of excitation energy.
elements.clean_text: In order to understand the mechanism of luminescence quenching of Fe(III) ions suspension, the PXRD of the sample after fluorescence testing was measured (Figure S10). The unchanged pattern suggests that the quenching of photoluminescence has no relation with the crystallographic transformation, indicating that Fe(III) ions would not induce framework collapse. According to UV-vis absorption spectra (Figure S11), the strong adsorption of the aqueous solution of Fe(III) ions is in the range of 250-450 nm, while others do not overlap in this range, especially near the 283 nm. Therefore, there exists obvious competition of the absorption in excitation wavelength (283 nm) between TbL and the Fe(III) ions water solution. Such competitive adsorption will significantly decrease the transfer efficiency of excitation energy.

elements.content: In order to explore the porosity of 1–4, we choose the TbL as an example to investigate the porosity of the framework through gas sorption experiments. The fresh TbL first was guest-exchanged with dry CH2Cl2 for three times in 3 days, then activated at 150 °C under 10 μmHg for 10 h. The sorption isotherms for N2, CH4, and CO2 are expressed in a. The sorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 show the typical Type-I, indicating the retention of the microporous structures after the removal of guests from the crystalline samples. At 77 K, almost no N2 absorption was observed, while CH4 and CO2 show obvious absorption at 273 and 295 K. The maximum uptakes of CO2 are 38.21 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 33.10 cm3·g–1 at 295 K and 1.0 bar, which are much higher compared with CH4 (10.13 cm3·g–1 at 273 K and 7.61 cm3·g–1 at 295 K and 1.0 bar). For TbL, it exhibits obvious selective adsorption of CO2 over CH4, although the uptake values are not high compared with some reported results. The adsorption performance could be ascribed to the host–guest interactions and microporous structure. TbL contains open imidazolyl active sites and unsaturated metal sites in the framework, which may lead to an electric field to induce a dipole in CO2. The lowest isosteric heat (Q st) of CO2 has been estimated at more than 30 kJ mol–1 (b), which reflects a strong adsorbent–adsorbate interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Properties

In order to explore the porosity of 1-4, we choose the TbL as an example to investigate the porosity of the framework through gas sorption experiments. The fresh TbL first was guest-exchanged with dry CH2Cl2 for three times in 3 days, then activated at 150 °C under 10 μmHg for 10 h. The sorption isotherms for N2, CH4, and CO2 are expressed in a. The sorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 show the typical Type-I, indicating the retention of the microporous structures after the removal of guests from the crystalline samples. At 77 K, almost no N2 absorption was observed, while CH4 and CO2 show obvious absorption at 273 and 295 K. The maximum uptakes of CO2 are 38.21 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 33.10 cm3⋅g-1 at 295 K and 1.0 bar, which are much higher compared with CH4 (10.13 cm3⋅g-1 at 273 K and 7.61 cm3⋅g-1 at 295 K and 1.0 bar). For TbL, it exhibits obvious selective adsorption of CO2 over CH4, although the uptake values are not high compared with some reported results. The adsorption performance could be ascribed to the host-guest interactions and microporous structure. TbL contains open imidazolyl active sites and unsaturated metal sites in the framework, which may lead to an electric field to induce a dipole in CO2. The lowest isosteric heat (Q st) of CO2 has been estimated at more than 30 kJ mol-1 (b), which reflects a strong adsorbent-adsorbate interaction.

elements.content: (a) CO2 and CH4 uptake capacity for TbL at 295 K, and N2 uptake capacity at 77 K. (b) The Q st of TbL for CO2. (c) The CO2/CH4 selectivity of TbL for the 15/85 CO2/CH4 mixture at 1 bar and 273 K.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) CO2 and CH4 uptake capacity for TbL at 295 K, and N2 uptake capacity at 77 K. (b) The Q st of TbL for CO2. (c) The CO2/CH4 selectivity of TbL for the 15/85 CO2/CH4 mixture at 1 bar and 273 K.

elements.content: Ideal adsorbed solution theory was utilized to study the feasibility of TbL to selectively separate CO2 from binary CO2/CH4 mixtures. As shown in c, the selectivity exhibits a rapid decline trend in the low pressure. The values of selectivity are all above 80, which indicates good selectivity compared with some reported MOFs. Although the adsorption capacity of TbL for CO2 is not remarkable, it shows a particular capturing ability of CO2 over some gases with high selectivity, indicating that TbL may be a potential candidate in selective gas separation.
elements.clean_text: Ideal adsorbed solution theory was utilized to study the feasibility of TbL to selectively separate CO2 from binary CO2/CH4 mixtures. As shown in c, the selectivity exhibits a rapid decline trend in the low pressure. The values of selectivity are all above 80, which indicates good selectivity compared with some reported MOFs. Although the adsorption capacity of TbL for CO2 is not remarkable, it shows a particular capturing ability of CO2 over some gases with high selectivity, indicating that TbL may be a potential candidate in selective gas separation.

elements.content: Considering that the TbL has coordinative unsaturated metal sites after activation 3 h in 150 °C, it may possess catalytic performance. We chose the styrene oxide as a typical reactant to find the optimal condition in the reaction of CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides, and the experimental results are shown in . First, the influence of TbL toward this reaction was investigated under the solvent-free conditions with 0.1 MPa CO2 at 70 °C. When we added TbL catalyst and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBBA) cocatalyst simultaneously (entry 3), it has a notably higher yield (89.7%) compared with adding only one of them (entry 2, <1% and entry 1, 31.6%), suggesting both TbL and TBBA play the important roles in this reaction. Then the suitable temperature for the reaction was explored under the conditions with 0.1 MPa CO2, 3.5 mol % TbL, and 3.5 mol % TBBA. The corresponding yields were 56.7% at 60 °C and 90.1% at 80 °C (entry 4 and entry 5). The yield declined obviously when the temperature dropped to 60 °C. Although the yield was increased by raising the temperature (entry 5), the yield cannot increase obviously when heating up to 80 °C (90.1%) compared with the condition of 70 °C (89.7%, entry 3). Therefore, to avoid excessive energy consumption at high temperature, we chose the milder condition (70 °C). Thus, we get the optimum reaction conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Properties

Considering that the TbL has coordinative unsaturated metal sites after activation 3 h in 150 °C, it may possess catalytic performance. We chose the styrene oxide as a typical reactant to find the optimal condition in the reaction of CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides, and the experimental results are shown in . First, the influence of TbL toward this reaction was investigated under the solvent-free conditions with 0.1 MPa CO2 at 70 °C. When we added TbL catalyst and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBBA) cocatalyst simultaneously (entry 3), it has a notably higher yield (89.7%) compared with adding only one of them (entry 2, <1% and entry 1, 31.6%), suggesting both TbL and TBBA play the important roles in this reaction. Then the suitable temperature for the reaction was explored under the conditions with 0.1 MPa CO2, 3.5 mol % TbL, and 3.5 mol % TBBA. The corresponding yields were 56.7% at 60 °C and 90.1% at 80 °C (entry 4 and entry 5). The yield declined obviously when the temperature dropped to 60 °C. Although the yield was increased by raising the temperature (entry 5), the yield cannot increase obviously when heating up to 80 °C (90.1%) compared with the condition of 70 °C (89.7%, entry 3). Therefore, to avoid excessive energy consumption at high temperature, we chose the milder condition (70 °C). Thus, we get the optimum reaction conditions.

elements.content:
Cycloaddition of CO<sub>2</sub> with Styrene Oxide under Different Conditions<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref> entry catalyst (mol %) TBAB (mol %) T (°C) yield (mol %) 1 0 3.5 70 31.6 2 3.5 0 70 <1 3 3.5 3.5 70 89.7 4 3.5 3.5 60 56.7 5 3.5 3.5 80 90.1

Reaction conditions: styrene oxide (600.8 mg, 5.0 mmol), CO2 (0.1 MPa), TbL (3.5 mol %, 76 mg), TBAB (59.5 mg, 3.5 mol %), 12 h.

Total yield calculated according to 1H NMR spectroscopy.

To further investigate the catalytic performance of TbL, some epoxides substrates were chosen for this reaction, and the corresponding results are shown in . Under the optimum conditions, the corresponding results of entry 1–4 were obtained in excellent yields (87.5–99%), especially 2-(chloromethyl)­oxirane with the corresponding yield of 99%, while entry 5 and 6 got low yield (45.5% and 37.2%). The results indicate that TbL possesses catalytic performance in the reaction of CO2 cycloaddition. The correlation between the yields and the different substrates is consistent with the observation in the previous literature, which can be explained that the electron-withdrawing substituents can promote nucleophilic attack in the course of the ring opening step, while the electron-donating substituents are converted to the corresponding products with relatively low yields. In addition, recycling experiments were investigated over catalyst TbL for the styrene oxide cycloaddition reaction. As shown in , the catalyst can be easily filtered, washed, and recycled for three runs.
elements.clean_text: To further investigate the catalytic performance of TbL, some epoxides substrates were chosen for this reaction, and the corresponding results are shown in . Under the optimum conditions, the corresponding results of entry 1-4 were obtained in excellent yields (87.5-99%), especially 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane with the corresponding yield of 99%, while entry 5 and 6 got low yield (45.5% and 37.2%). The results indicate that TbL possesses catalytic performance in the reaction of CO2 cycloaddition. The correlation between the yields and the different substrates is consistent with the observation in the previous literature, which can be explained that the electron-withdrawing substituents can promote nucleophilic attack in the course of the ring opening step, while the electron-donating substituents are converted to the corresponding products with relatively low yields. In addition, recycling experiments were investigated over catalyst TbL for the styrene oxide cycloaddition reaction. As shown in , the catalyst can be easily filtered, washed, and recycled for three runs.

elements.content:
Various Cyclic Carbonates from CO<sub>2</sub> and Epoxides with Catalyst <bold>TbL</bold> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t2fn1"></xref>

Reaction conditions: 0.1 MPa CO2, 5.0 mmol of epoxides, 3.5 mol % TbL (76 mg), 3.5 mol % TBAB (59.5 mg), 70 °C, 12 h.

Total yield calculated according to 1H NMR spectroscopy.
Recycle experiment of TbL for cycloaddition of CO2 with styrene oxide.
elements.clean_text: 6  Recycle experiment of TbL for cycloaddition of CO2 with styrene oxide.

elements.content: In summary, by utilizing a tricarboxylate linker with versatile coordination modes and Lewis basic sites, we have designed and synthesized a novel 3D Ln-MOF with the channel of 7.8 Å × 12.1 Å size, which shows the outstanding thermal, air, and chemical stabilities. The luminescent sensing experiment suggests that TbL can sensitively detect Fe­(III) ions in the mixed solution containing both Fe­(II) and Fe­(III) ions, which can be used in detecting hydrogen peroxide oxidization reaction progress of Fe­(II) to Fe­(III) ions in industry. Furthermore, the material has potential application prospects in CO2 capture and utilization which can selectively adsorb CO2 over CH4 and catalyze the cyclization reaction with epoxides and CO2. The above results shed some new light on the design and construction of stable, multifunctional lanthanide metal–organic materials in luminescence sensing and carbon dioxide conversion by multicarboxylate ligands with Lewis basic sites.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, by utilizing a tricarboxylate linker with versatile coordination modes and Lewis basic sites, we have designed and synthesized a novel 3D Ln-MOF with the channel of 7.8 Å × 12.1 Å size, which shows the outstanding thermal, air, and chemical stabilities. The luminescent sensing experiment suggests that TbL can sensitively detect Fe(III) ions in the mixed solution containing both Fe(II) and Fe(III) ions, which can be used in detecting hydrogen peroxide oxidization reaction progress of Fe(II) to Fe(III) ions in industry. Furthermore, the material has potential application prospects in CO2 capture and utilization which can selectively adsorb CO2 over CH4 and catalyze the cyclization reaction with epoxides and CO2. The above results shed some new light on the design and construction of stable, multifunctional lanthanide metal-organic materials in luminescence sensing and carbon dioxide conversion by multicarboxylate ligands with Lewis basic sites.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of H3L (29 mg, 0.10 mmol) and Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O (45 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in a 10 mL binary solution (CH3CN/H2O = 1:1), which was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Then they were kept in a 130 °C oven for 72 h. After slowly being cooled to room temperature, the colorless crystals were collected by filtration, washed with CH3CN and ethanol, and dried in air. The total yields of EuL, GdL, TbL, and DyL are ca. 60%, 65%, 63%, and 61%, respectively, based on the metal ions. The elemental analyses are as follows.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [LnL(H2O)2]⋅H2O (Ln = Eu, Gd, Tb, and Dy) (Compounds EuL, GdL, TbL and DyL)

A mixture of H3L (29 mg, 0.10 mmol) and Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (45 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in a 10 mL binary solution (CH3CN/H2O = 1:1), which was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Then they were kept in a 130 °C oven for 72 h. After slowly being cooled to room temperature, the colorless crystals were collected by filtration, washed with CH3CN and ethanol, and dried in air. The total yields of EuL, GdL, TbL, and DyL are ca. 60%, 65%, 63%, and 61%, respectively, based on the metal ions. The elemental analyses are as follows.

cln_elements.content:
In spite of the high performance in many fields, a crucial weakness which hinders the applications of MOFs is their low stability. Thus, a comprehensive stability investigation of the material was then carried out. The TGA data (Figure S4) demonstrate that the decomposition temperature of the framework is high up to 440 °C. The first weight loss appears in the range of ca. 30–100 °C, which corresponds to the removal of the water molecules in the pores. And the weight loss in the range of ca. 100–240 °C corresponds to the removal of the coordinated water. The X-ray thermodiffractogram of TbL was investigated to further explore the thermal stability of the framework (a). The result shows no obvious phase transition occurs when heated up to 180 °C, but some characteristic peaks become inconspicuous when we raise the temperature to 200 °C, suggesting that this framework could remain stable until heating up to 180 °C. For an air stability test, 40 mg of TbL was exposed to the open air for 7, 15, and 30 days with an average humidity of ca. 55%. The PXRD patterns were then recorded to test its air stability. The result shown in b suggests that TbL can keep its framework after exposure to the open air for more than 30 days. To test its water stability, 40 mg of TbL was soaked in 25 mL of water for 3, 7, 15, and 30 days. The corresponding PXRD results suggest that TbL possesses excellent stability to water (c). Chemical stability test was assessed by soaking the 40 mg of TbL in the aqueous solutions of pH = 1–14 for 48 h. Then, all the samples were filtered and washed 3 times and dried in air before PXRD experiments for pH stability tests. The result reveals that the framework can remain stable in a broad pH range (pH = 2–12) (d). Overall, this framework shows strong stabilities toward high temperature, humid air, water, as well as acid/basic environments.

Gas Sorption Properties

In order to explore the porosity of 1–4, we choose the TbL as an example to investigate the porosity of the framework through gas sorption experiments. The fresh TbL first was guest-exchanged with dry CH2Cl2 for three times in 3 days, then activated at 150 °C under 10 μmHg for 10 h. The sorption isotherms for N2, CH4, and CO2 are expressed in a. The sorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 show the typical Type-I, indicating the retention of the microporous structures after the removal of guests from the crystalline samples. At 77 K, almost no N2 absorption was observed, while CH4 and CO2 show obvious absorption at 273 and 295 K. The maximum uptakes of CO2 are 38.21 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 33.10 cm3·g–1 at 295 K and 1.0 bar, which are much higher compared with CH4 (10.13 cm3·g–1 at 273 K and 7.61 cm3·g–1 at 295 K and 1.0 bar). For TbL, it exhibits obvious selective adsorption of CO2 over CH4, although the uptake values are not high compared with some reported results. The adsorption performance could be ascribed to the host–guest interactions and microporous structure. TbL contains open imidazolyl active sites and unsaturated metal sites in the framework, which may lead to an electric field to induce a dipole in CO2. The lowest isosteric heat (Q st) of CO2 has been estimated at more than 30 kJ mol–1 (b), which reflects a strong adsorbent–adsorbate interaction.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Framework Stability

In spite of the high performance in many fields, a crucial weakness which hinders the applications of MOFs is their low stability. Thus, a comprehensive stability investigation of the material was then carried out. The TGA data (Figure S4) demonstrate that the decomposition temperature of the framework is high up to 440 °C. The first weight loss appears in the range of ca. 30-100 °C, which corresponds to the removal of the water molecules in the pores. And the weight loss in the range of ca. 100-240 °C corresponds to the removal of the coordinated water. The X-ray thermodiffractogram of TbL was investigated to further explore the thermal stability of the framework (a). The result shows no obvious phase transition occurs when heated up to 180 °C, but some characteristic peaks become inconspicuous when we raise the temperature to 200 °C, suggesting that this framework could remain stable until heating up to 180 °C. For an air stability test, 40 mg of TbL was exposed to the open air for 7, 15, and 30 days with an average humidity of ca. 55%. The PXRD patterns were then recorded to test its air stability. The result shown in b suggests that TbL can keep its framework after exposure to the open air for more than 30 days. To test its water stability, 40 mg of TbL was soaked in 25 mL of water for 3, 7, 15, and 30 days. The corresponding PXRD results suggest that TbL possesses excellent stability to water (c). Chemical stability test was assessed by soaking the 40 mg of TbL in the aqueous solutions of pH = 1-14 for 48 h. Then, all the samples were filtered and washed 3 times and dried in air before PXRD experiments for pH stability tests. The result reveals that the framework can remain stable in a broad pH range (pH = 2-12) (d). Overall, this framework shows strong stabilities toward high temperature, humid air, water, as well as acid/basic environments.

Gas Sorption Properties

In order to explore the porosity of 1-4, we choose the TbL as an example to investigate the porosity of the framework through gas sorption experiments. The fresh TbL first was guest-exchanged with dry CH2Cl2 for three times in 3 days, then activated at 150 °C under 10 μmHg for 10 h. The sorption isotherms for N2, CH4, and CO2 are expressed in a. The sorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 show the typical Type-I, indicating the retention of the microporous structures after the removal of guests from the crystalline samples. At 77 K, almost no N2 absorption was observed, while CH4 and CO2 show obvious absorption at 273 and 295 K. The maximum uptakes of CO2 are 38.21 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 33.10 cm3⋅g-1 at 295 K and 1.0 bar, which are much higher compared with CH4 (10.13 cm3⋅g-1 at 273 K and 7.61 cm3⋅g-1 at 295 K and 1.0 bar). For TbL, it exhibits obvious selective adsorption of CO2 over CH4, although the uptake values are not high compared with some reported results. The adsorption performance could be ascribed to the host-guest interactions and microporous structure. TbL contains open imidazolyl active sites and unsaturated metal sites in the framework, which may lead to an electric field to induce a dipole in CO2. The lowest isosteric heat (Q st) of CO2 has been estimated at more than 30 kJ mol-1 (b), which reflects a strong adsorbent-adsorbate interaction.

decomposition temperature.type: removal of water molecules in the pores
stable with no obvious phase transition

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of the Tb­(III) ion in TbL. (Symmetry codes: A, 1 – x, −y, −z; B, x, y–1, z–1; C, −x, −y–1, −z; D, x, y–1, z. Tb, green; N, blue; O, red; C, gray). (b) 1D [Tb2(μ2-COO)2] n chain in TbL. (c) The coordination mode of ligand. (d) The 3D network of TbL viewed along the b axis.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of the Tb(III) ion in TbL. (Symmetry codes: A, 1 - x, -y, -z; B, x, y-1, z-1; C, -x, -y-1, -z; D, x, y-1, z. Tb, green; N, blue; O, red; C, gray). (b) 1D [Tb2(μ2-COO)2] n  chain in TbL. (c) The coordination mode of ligand. (d) The 3D network of TbL viewed along the b axis.

cln_elements.content: X-ray thermodiffractogram (a), air stability (b), water stability (c), and pH stability (d) analyses of TbL.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  X-ray thermodiffractogram (a), air stability (b), water stability (c), and pH stability (d) analyses of TbL.

cln_elements.content: Excitation and emission spectra of EuL (a) and TbL (b) at room temperature.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Excitation and emission spectra of EuL (a) and TbL (b) at room temperature.

cln_elements.content: (a) Luminescence intensity of the 5D4 → 7F5 transitions (543 nm) of TbL in 5 × 10–4 M different metal cations. (b) The luminescence image of corresponding Fe­(III) ions and Fe­(II) ions samples under the irradiation of UV light. (c) The fluorescence intensity of Fe­(III) ions and Fe­(II) ions aqueous solution with 1 mmol/L total concentration.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Luminescence intensity of the 5D4 → 7F5 transitions (543 nm) of TbL in 5 × 10-4 M different metal cations. (b) The luminescence image of corresponding Fe(III) ions and Fe(II) ions samples under the irradiation of UV light. (c) The fluorescence intensity of Fe(III) ions and Fe(II) ions aqueous solution with 1 mmol/L total concentration.

cln_elements.content: (a) CO2 and CH4 uptake capacity for TbL at 295 K, and N2 uptake capacity at 77 K. (b) The Q st of TbL for CO2. (c) The CO2/CH4 selectivity of TbL for the 15/85 CO2/CH4 mixture at 1 bar and 273 K.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  (a) CO2 and CH4 uptake capacity for TbL at 295 K, and N2 uptake capacity at 77 K. (b) The Q st of TbL for CO2. (c) The CO2/CH4 selectivity of TbL for the 15/85 CO2/CH4 mixture at 1 bar and 273 K.

cln_elements.content: Recycle experiment of TbL for cycloaddition of CO2 with styrene oxide.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Recycle experiment of TbL for cycloaddition of CO2 with styrene oxide.

metadata.title:
Fabrication of a Robust Lanthanide Metal–Organic
Framework as a Multifunctional Material for Fe(III) Detection, CO2 Capture, and Utilization
